column1: A parasite is an organism (a living thing) that lives on or inside another organism.
Although different forms of leishmaniasis affect people in different ways
column2: the most common type causes skin sores.

column1: See your healthcare provider if you think you have leishmaniasis.
Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by an infection with Leishmania parasites
column2: which are spread by the bite of infected sand flies. Leishmaniasis is a neglected tropical disease (NTD).

column1: There are several different forms of leishmaniasis in people:
Cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL): the most common form
Mucosal leishmaniasis (ML): a severe type of CL that can cause sores in the nose
column3: or throat. ML can be life threatening.

column1: Visceral leishmaniasis (VL): this is a less common form
column3: which affects internal organs. If not treated
column4: severe cases of VL can be deadly.

column1: Signs and symptoms can vary based on the form of leishmaniasis. People may or may not experience signs and symptoms.
Those who develop symptoms have one or more skin sores
column2: which can change in size and appearance over time. The skin sores usually develop within a few weeks or months of the sand fly bite. The sores are often painless.

column1: ML is a form of leishmaniasis that affects the mucous membranes (most commonly the nose
column2: but also the mouth and throat). ML can be a consequence of infection with some of the types of parasites that cause CL in parts of Central and South America and

column1: VL is another form of leishmaniasis caused by a small number of Leishmania species. People with VL may develop fever
column3: and anemia (low red blood cells). VL often goes on to affect internal organs (especially the spleen
column5: and bone marrow) and can be life threatening. People with VL usually become sick within months (though it can be years) of the sand fly bite. If untreated

column1: Anyone who lives in or travels to an area where Leishmania parasites occur and is bitten by an infected sand fly is at risk for leishmaniasis. It is usually more common in rural areas but can also occur in the outskirts of some cities. Dusk to dawn is the time when people are most likely to be bitten.
Leishmaniasis occurs in parts of approximately 90 countries
column2: usually in tropical or subtropical climates.

column1: Most cases of leishmaniasis that are diagnosed in the US are in people who were infected while traveling or living in other countries.

column2: people have had locally acquired CL
column3: especially in Texas and rarely other states (e.g.
column4: Oklahoma and Arizona). There have been no known cases of acquired VL in the US.

column1: The main way people get infected with leishmaniasis is through the bite of an infected female sand fly. People may not notice the bites because sand flies are silent
column3: and the bites can be painless for many people. On average
column4: sand flies that transmit the parasite are only about one fourth the size of mosquitoes (sometimes even smaller).

column1: Sand flies are usually most active at twilight

Some species of Leishmania parasites can also be spread via contaminated needles (needle sharing) or blood transfusions. There have also been reports of congenital transmission (mother passing an infection to her baby during pregnancy or at birth).
There are no vaccines or drugs to prevent leishmaniasis. The best way to prevent infection is to protect yourself from sand fly bites through preventive measures.
Even if you already had leishmaniasis
column2: it is possible to get it again. Therefore
column3: it is important to follow preventive measures.

column1: If you have traveled or lived in a part of the world where leishmaniasis occurs and have symptoms

CDC staff can advise your healthcare provider and help with laboratory testing for leishmaniasis. Your healthcare provider will test tissue samples from skin sores (for CL) or from bone marrow (for VL) to examine for diagnosis. Blood tests can be helpful for VL.
CDC staff can advise your healthcare provider on whether your case of leishmaniasis should be treated
Different types of treatment are available for CL and the choice of treatment depends on multiple factors
column2: including the species of Leishmania parasite involved. In some cases
column3: skin sores from CL might heal on their own without treatment depending on the species involved. Leishmania skin sores can take months to years to heal and the sores can leave significant scars.

column1: For the Leishmania species that cause ML
column2: it is important to have proper treatment in order to prevent mucosal tissue destruction in the nose
column5: ML can be life threatening if it affects the throat.

column1: It is important to recognize and treat VL early. If not treated
column2: severe (advanced) cases of VL are typically deadly. In people with compromised immune systems (e.g.
column5: VL can be difficult to treat.

column1: Kawasaki disease (KD) can cause heart and blood vessel damage.
It occurs mostly in children younger than 5 years old.
It affects boys more often than girls.
KD symptoms include fever that lasts at least 5 days plus at least 1 other common disease symptom.
Speak with a healthcare provider if your child has symptoms of KD.

column3: is a disease that can cause damage to the heart and blood vessels
column4: mostly in children younger than 5 years old. It affects boys more often than girls. The cause of KD is not known.

column2: it's estimated that KD occurs in 9 to 20 per 100

column3: 000 children under 18 years of age who were hospitalized with KD in the United States. Of these children
column5: 693 were under 5 years of age; this means there was a hospitalization rate of 18.9 per 100

column1: Children may have all or just some of the signs and symptoms of Kawasaki Disease.
Children with KD have a fever that typically lasts for 5 days or longer. They may also have some or all of the following symptoms:
Swelling and redness of their hands and feet
Irritation and redness of the whites of their eyes
Swollen lymph glands in their neck
Irritation and inflammation of their mouth

column2: including swelling of parts of the heart and other blood vessels. When this happens
column3: the heart doesn't work as well to pump blood to the body and could burst (coronary artery dilation and aneurysms).

column1: Surveillance and reporting for healthcare professionals

column2: CDC defines a case of KD as illness in a patient with fever that lasts 5 or more days (or fever until the intravenous immunoglobulin is given
column3: if given before the fifth day of fever)
column4: and having at least 4 of the following 5 clinical signs:

column1: Swelling and redness of their hands and feet
Cervical lymphadenopathy (at least 15 cm in diameter)
Patients whose illness does not meet the above KD case definition but have fever and coronary artery abnormalities are classified as having atypical or incomplete KD.
The CDC standardized KD case report form is available as a PDF document for healthcare workers to submit a report. If you are a healthcare professional and wish to submit a report
column2: you can either print the form and fill it out by hand or fill it out electronically and print it out. The completed form should be sent to the mailing address provided on the form or sent by fax to 404-471-8768.

and it must be given at the hospital. It typically combines a mixture of antibodies given through your veins (intravenous immunoglobulin) and aspirin. The treatment can help make symptoms less severe and reduce the risk of serious complications. Healthcare professionals may recommend additional treatments.

There are reports of illnesses that look like Kawasaki disease after infection with SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes COVID-19). This is called multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C).

column1: Most people will come into contact with Acanthamoeba at some point
column2: but most won't get sick. Although rare
column3: some people develop serious Acanthamoeba infections that are often fatal.

column1: See a healthcare provider right away if you have symptoms of an Acanthamoeba infection.
Most people will be exposed to Acanthamoeba during their lifetime. The ameba is found in soil and dust as well fresh water and saltwater. It can also be found in swimming pools
Most people exposed to Acanthamoeba won't get sick. For others
column2: it can cause serious infections of the brain
column5: and sinuses. Acanthamoeba can infect parts of the body through cuts or skin wounds or from being inhaled into the lungs or nostrils. It can get into the eyes through contact lens use.

column1: High resolution of Acanthamoeba in a patient's brain
Non-keratitis Acanthamoeba infections are rare but serious infections that can affect one or many parts of the body. These infections usually occur in people with weakened immune systems and include:

column2: which affects the brain and is almost always fatal
an infection of the nasal cavity and sinuses
which affects multiple parts of the body. GAE
column4: and Acanthamoeba rhinosinusitis can all spread to cause disseminated infections.

column1: Acanthamoeba keratitis is an eye infection that typically occurs in healthy people and can cause permanent vision loss. Most people in the United States who get this infection wear contact lenses. The infection usually doesn't spread to other parts of the body.

A free-living ameba is a kind of one-celled organism that lives in water and soil around the world. Most people will come into contact with these amebas during their lives but won't get sick. Others will develop rare but serious infections.
Although there are several types of free-living amebas that live in the environment
column2: three are known to cause severe disease in people:

column1: All of these amebas can cause life-threatening brain infections. Some can also cause infections of the eyes
column4: and other parts of the body.

column1: Fungal eye infections are extremely rare but can be very serious.
Most fungal eye infections occur from eye injuries.
Eye surgeries and bloodstream infections can also cause fungal eye infections.
Fungal eye infections are treated with prescription antifungal medications.

column2: a fungus that causes eye infections.

column1: Eye infections can be caused by many different organisms
column5: and fungi. Eye infections caused by fungi are extremely rare but can be very serious.

column1: There are two main types of fungal eye infections
column2: depending on the part of the eye that is infected. Many types of fungi can cause eye infections.

column1: The two types of fungal eye infections are keratitis and endophthalmitis. Keratitis is an infection of the clear
column2: front layer of the eye (the cornea). Endophthalmitis is an infection of the inside of the eye (the vitreous and/or aqueous humor).

column1: Endophthalmitis can occur two different ways. Exogenous fungal endophthalmitis occurs after fungal spores enter the eye from an external source. Endogenous fungal endophthalmitis occurs when a bloodstream infection (for example
column2: candidemia) spreads to one or both eyes.

column1: Many types of fungi can cause infections.

column2: especially in soil and on plants.

column1: Aspergillus – common mold foundi n indoor and outdoor environments.
Candida – a type of yeast that normally lives in and on the body.
The symptoms of a fungal eye infection can show up anytime from several days to several weeks after an exposure. Fungal eye infection symptoms are similar to those of other types of eye infections
A fungal eye infection can be caused by:
Eye surgery or invasive eye procedures.
Contaminated medical products are a potential risk factor.
Chronic eye disease involving the surface of the eye.

column3: or use corticosteroids (anti-inflammatory steroids) have a higher risk of fungal eye infections. Fungal keratitis may be more common among people living in rural areas.

column1: Eye infections can occur after eye surgery.
Wearing eye protection when outside can help prevent fungal eye infections caused by eye injuries that involve plant material. For many activities
column2: wearing sunglasses can offer some protection. Outdoor workers and farmworkers should wear appropriate protective eyewear.

column1: People who wear contact lenses should care for their lenses properly. Learn more about how to protect your eyes while wearing contacts.
If you think you have an eye infection it is important to see a healthcare provider or eye doctor right away.
An eye doctor can examine your eye and test for infection.

The most common way to diagnose a fungal eye infection is done by a doctor collecting a sample of tissue or fluid from the eye. The sample is sent to a laboratory to be examined under a microscope or cultured.
Polymerase chain reaction and confocal microscopy
column3: are also being used as newer

column1: The treatment for a fungal eye infection depends on the type of fungus
column3: and the parts of the eye that are affected. Possible forms of treatment for fungal eye infections include:

column1: Antifungal medication given as a pill.
Eye surgery may be needed if infections do not get better after using antifungal medications.
To lower your risk of kidney and renal pelvis cancers
Be very careful if you work with the chemical trichloroethylene.
Kidney and renal pelvis cancer is a disease in which cells in the kidney grow out of control. It can also be called renal cell cancer
column2: as that is the most common type of kidney and renal pelvis cancer.

column2: one on each side of the body
column3: located behind the liver and stomach. The kidneys make urine
column4: which is how the body washes liquid waste out of the body. The kidneys also play a role in controlling blood pressure and stimulating the bone marrow to make red blood cells.

column1: The renal pelvis is in the center of the kidney and is responsible for collecting the urine and feeding it into the ureters
column2: two tubes that connect the kidneys with the bladder. The bladder holds urine until it leaves the body.

column1: A person with kidney or renal pelvis cancer may or may not have one or more of the symptoms listed here. The same symptoms can also come from other causes. If you have any of these symptoms
A lump or swelling in the kidney area or abdomen.
Lower back pain or pain in the side that doesn't go away.
Losing weight for no reason that you know of.
A general feeling of poor health.
Risk factors for kidney and renal pelvis cancers include:
Having high blood pressure. It is not known whether the increased risk is due to high blood pressure itself or the medicines used to treat it.
Taking certain pain medicines for a long time.
Having a long-lasting infection with hepatitis C.

column2: which is associated with a very rare form of kidney cancer (renal medullary carcinoma).

column1: Being exposed to a chemical called trichloroethylene
column2: which is used to remove grease from metal.

column1: To lower your risk of kidney and renal pelvis cancers:
Be very careful if you use certain kinds of chemicals
column2: especially trichloroethylene. This chemical is used by workers in some jobs
column3: like those that work with metals.

Klebsiella is a type of bacteria normally found in human stool (feces) that can cause healthcare-associated infections (HAIs).
Some Klebsiella bacteria are becoming increasingly resistant to antibiotics.
Klebsiella is a type of gram-negative bacteria normally found in human stool (feces) that can cause HAIs. Klebsiella are becoming increasingly resistant to antibiotics
column2: including carbapenems (often the last line of defense against multidrug-resistant bacterial infections).
Klebsiella infections commonly occur among sick patients receiving treatment for other conditions. Patients with devices like ventilators (breathing machines) or intravenous (vein) catheters
column3: and patients taking long courses of certain antibiotics are most at risk for Klebsiella infections.

column1: Healthy people usually do not get Klebsiella infections.
Contact with contaminated water or soil.
Wounds caused by injury or surgery.
Klebsiella does not spread through the air.
Patients should clean their hands often
Before and after changing wound dressings or bandages.
After touching hospital surfaces such as bed rails
Healthcare staff should always follow core infection control practices to reduce the risk of spreading these germs to patients.
To determine if someone has a Klebsiella infection
column2: healthcare providers will send a specimen to the laboratory. Testing can also determine what treatment will work best.

column1: Klebsiella infections are generally treated with antibiotics. Unfortunately
column2: some Klebsiella bacteria (germs) are resistant to multiple antibiotics
column3: which makes them difficult to treat.

column1: Tracking Klebsiella infections through the Emerging Infections Program and National Healthcare Safety Network
column2: and resistance testing for some species through the Antimicrobial Resistance Laboratory Network.

column1: Data is also available on the AR & Patient Safety Portal

column3: healthcare providers and patients to prevent infections caused by Klebsiella and slow the spread of resistant germs.

column1: Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) is a viral disease mostly found in southern India.
Spread to people primarily occurs through tick bites or contact with infected animals.
There is a vaccine available for people at risk for KFD.
Between 400 and 500 people get KFD every year.

Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) is a serious disease first identified in the Kyasanur Forest of India. It is caused by the KFD virus. Hard ticks (Hemaphysalis spinigera) spread the KFD virus to people and to animals
KFD is found in the Karnataka
Most people with KFD have a sudden onset of chills
column6: and bleeding can follow 3 or 4 days after symptoms begin.

column1: Most patients recover one to two weeks after symptoms begin. About 10 to 20% of patients experience a second wave of symptoms
How long it takes for signs to show
People with KFD usually start having symptoms 3-8 days after being infected with the virus.

column6: and Kerala states of India are at higher risk for getting KFD. This is because they are more likely to be bitten by infected ticks.

column1: Travelers visiting a location with known or history of KFD spread are at risk of infection.
People are more likely to get KFD during the dry season of November to June.
People get KFD from infected tick bites or exposure to an infected animal.
Infected ticks can live on livestock
column2: but livestock rarely spread KFD to people.

column1: KFD does not spread between people.
The KSD virus spreads from ticks to animals and people
Use insect repellent containing DEET to prevent tick bites.
Get vaccinated if you live in an area where KFD is found.
Avoid contact with dead or sick animals
Healthcare providers diagnose KFD with the following tests:
Detection of antibodies in the blood
There is no cure for KFD.

column2: many patients recover from KFD without complications. However
column3: about 3 to 5% of people with the disease will die.

column1: A vaccine for KFD is available and recommended in the parts of India where KFD is found.
CDC is monitoring the spread of KFD. CDC also provides guidance on prevention and management of KFD to international public health partners.
